indicator: Semantic interoperability within the DES is facilitated through either policy or technical means
Data is shared in (near) real-time through the DES
Technology architecture of the DES is scalable
Data exchange has a federation capability
A public-interest entity governs the development and operations of the DES
Use of the DES is subject to transparent enrollment and participation conditions
Data exchange instances within the DES can be monitored in public-interest
Data exchange governance is regularly reviewed and reported on
Data exchange governance is informed by a multi-stakeholder group of representatives (especially from civil society, domain experts)
Procedural rules for the DES (access restrictions, protections, etc.) are established
Personal data on the exchange is protected by law
Data and system security standards are publicly disclosed
Data exchange is regularly reviewed for data protection and cyber resilience
Data exchange across government is implemented by a coordination unit
Strategy for skills training and retention is established
Budget for management of the data exchange is dedicated, reliable, sufficient
Public entities (other than the operator of the DES) leverage the data exchange
Data exchange is cross-sectoral
Private entities leverage the data exchange
Civil society entities leverage the data exchange
